content: Do I understand correctly that you want all messages you receive from a certain sender to be automatically forwarded to another address? Tools | Message Filters can do that. I think they are self-explanatory for you to set up yourself, but if you want help, just ask here.
creator: rednoise

content:
You can copy (not move) as many messages as you want to a local folder. You can then do whatever you want with them without affecting the originals. That includes exporting them. Stock Thunderbird is able to export them to individual eml files, which are text. The add-on "ImportExportTools NG" gives you many more export format options, including EML, HTML, PDF, CSV or plain text.

https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/importexporttools-ng/ .

content:
carol73 said
I dont know anything about troubleshooting mode, where do I find my version number? I tried to compose an email today and in it I put "reply to all" as soon as i typed this thunderbird would freeze and i would have to close it down and re-open-- after 3 times I realised what was causing the freeze. Does this happen to other people im sorry I'm not great with tech thanks for any help you can give carol

1. Troubleshoot mode

2. TB menu > Help > About Thunderbird

3. If it still happens in Troubleshoot mode, try this:

- go to TB menu > Settings > General 

- scroll all the way down and click the 'Config editor' button on the right 
- click 'Accept the risk and continue' if that appears 
- search for accessibility.force_disabled > change the value to 1 > click the check mark 
- restart TB and try again

content:
I don't understand your question. If you are trying to change your Mozilla account password, here is an article telling you how.

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/how-change-or-reset-your-mozilla-account-password

If you are trying to change the password for your email account, you can't do that from within Thunderbird - you have to go to your email provider's web site to do that. You can then, knowing with your new password, change the stored password within Thunderbird to agree with it.

Please be more specific as to what your intention is and we can give you some more details. If you're looking to change your email password, tell us what version of Thunderbird you're using, what your operating system is, and who your email provider is.

creator: martgorn

content:
It's very probable that Norton is the culprit. The common recommendation is to disable third-party anti-virus software or at least make an exception for Thunderbird in it.

You could test this hypothesis by starting Windows in safe mode with networking and seeing if Thunderbird retrieves messages with attachments. You could also just disable Norton and see if Thunderbird retrieves messages with attachments. I think that the former approach is considered better. I do not know why.

Or check Norton's quarantine, if it has one.
creator: mozilla98

Only time will tell.

content:
Try this first:

Open the TB profile:

- TB menu > Help > Troubleshooting information

- under the Application Basics section next to Profile Folder, click 'Open folder'

Close TB > rename the handlers.json file in your profile folder to handlers.old > restart TB

When you click a link now, you should be presented with a screen where you can choose which browser to use.

---

If that didn't work, try this:

Open the config editor:

- TB menu > Settings > General > scroll all the way down > click the 'Config editor' button

Search for and set these to true:

- network.protocol-handler.warn-external.http

- network.protocol-handler.warn-external.https

When you click a link now, you should be presented with a screen where you can choose which browser to use. Once done, reset the config options to false.
creator: siffemoz

content:
TB uses the operating system's default browser. Set Chrome as the default in Windows Settings, and also in Chrome settings.

Even if the default is set correctly, you might still receive links that aren't clickable, especially if they are sent from mobile mail apps such as on phones, or even from the Windows built-in mail app ('Outlook'). This can happen if the sender enters the URL directly in the message instead of embedding it in text.

content:
Hola, Lo sucede que no es una contraseña de inicio de aplicación es una contraseña maestra (como lo dice su nombre), es una contraseña para poder usar las contraseñas de los correos, sin ingresar esta contraseña maestra no puedes leer ni enviar correos nuevos ya que no puede conectarse con el servidor de correo. Para asegurar el acceso a la aplicación de Thunderbird lo tiene que hacer es iniciar sesión con contraseña del usuario del sistema como cualquier otro programa.

Saludos

content:
When you are first asked by Thunderbird to enter as password, there is a check box asking you if you want Thunderbird to remember it in the Password Manager (I forget how it's worded, but it's clear what it wants to do.) If you later want to change or delete that stored password, here's an article describing how:

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/password-manager-remember-delete-change-tb

creator: siffemoz

content:
Problem 1

The Outlook server is usually/always set to save sent messages, so the copy that Thunderbird saves is redundant.

In account settings > copies & folders, don't save sent messages. Then send yourself a message from your Outlook account to make sure that one copy is still being saved.


Problem 2

To troubleshoot, start Thunderbird in troubleshooting mode (Help menu > Troubleshoot mode) and see if the problem occurs.

Are you using add-ons?

What version of Thunderbird?
